content: Archimedes was a Greek mathematician and inventor from the city of Syracuse. He made important contributions to mathematics and physics, including calculating the ratios of the volumes of a sphere and its inscribed cylinder and cone, and determining the quadrature of parabolic segments. He also wrote about the principles of buoyancy and leverage and introduced an abstract number system to express large numbers. He was known for his practical insights and was well-regarded by the Roman upper class, who saw the value of mathematics and physics in military applications. Archimedes was killed during the Roman conquest of Syracuse, but he remains a revered figure in the history of mathematics.
